text:
WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Eliza + Eliza Wiggins
Address: Harvey, Sask.
Birthplace: Lakelet, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1887
Where did you set up housekeeping? A. W. Smith & Co., Lumsden, SASK.
Where had you been living before that? Ontario
For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
How far was it to your nearest store? 60 miles, Weyburn
How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice a year
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, sugar, oatmeal, rice - Baking Soda, etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? A. W. Smith & Co., Lumsden, SASK.
In what quantities did you buy it? 50 lbs.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.50
How much did you use Graham flour? 50 lbs.
Whole wheat flour? 50 lbs.
Was flour milled locally? Yes
How far away? 60 miles
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.50
What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal, whole wheat, farina
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
How did you grind it? Hand grinder

Received Aug. 17/51
William and Eliza Wiggins

1. What year did you start homesteading in eastern Oregon? 1882

   Where did you set up housekeeping? At the homestead.

   For how many people did you prepare food? 5

   How far was it to your nearest store? 10 miles

   How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly

   What provisions did you usually buy in those early years? Tea, sugar, oatmeal, rice, barley, pork

2. Flour and other grain products

   What brand or white flour did you use in the early years? Not sure

   In what quantities did you purchase flour? Not sure

   How much did you use per hundred pounds of flour?

   Whole wheat flour?

   Was flour milled locally?

   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?

   What other grain products did you use?

   Cornmeal?

   Oats?

   Did you grind your own flour for pancakes?

   How did you grind it? With a hand mill
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 1 lb. worth as we had money.

What was the price for a ton pound sack of white sugar? $5.00.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Golden Syrup.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb. Western Pail.

At what price? $6.50 per pail.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had cows.

Did you have cows or were they for sale? We had cows.

Butter? From cows.

Eggs? We had hens from which we got eggs.

What was the price of butter? $1.00.

Did you keep eggs for winter? Yes.

How? Salt, pepper, grease, broth, and other egg products.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Whole milk cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Hogs, hens, turkeys, and beef.

How did you get fresh meat? Killed it ourselves.

How often did you get fresh meat? When we needed it.

How did you preserve meat? Freeze in winter and cure for summer.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so, what year was it organized? Beef ring organized in 1905.

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Ducks.

For how long? Just for a change; we had stock.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Fish.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh.

Kinds?
3. SUGARS AND STARCHES

In what quantity did you buy molasses? $1.00 worth, 20 lbs. held away.

What was the price for a ton of sugar? $50.00

Which brand of flour did you buy? [illegible]

What size of tin of syrup did you buy? 10 lb. unwrapt, 10 lb. wrapped, 10 lb.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? [illegible]

Did you buy butter? [illegible]

Did you pack eggs for winter? [illegible]

Did you make butter? [illegible]

What kind of cheese? [illegible]

5. MEAT AND FISH

That was your meat supply in the early days? [illegible]

How often did you eat fresh meat? [illegible]

For how long? [illegible]
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? ........................................... At what price? ...........................................

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) ........................................... Price? ........................................... What other beverages were used? ...........................................

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping? ...........................................

Could you get potatoes at the store? ...........................................

If not, where from? ...........................................

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of? ...........................................

Potatoes ........................................... Cabbages ........................................... Carrots ........................................... Onions ...........................................

Turnips ........................................... Beets ...........................................

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? ...........................................

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? ...........................................

What weight? ........................................... How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? ...........................................

What was the price of prunes? ...........................................

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currents or others)? ...........................................

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? ...........................................

Pears? ........................................... Corn? ........................................... Beans? ........................................... Saskatoons? ...........................................

Other foods? ...........................................

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? ...........................................

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? ...........................................

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? ...........................................

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? ...........................................

To what extent? ...........................................

Did you make your own vinegar? ...........................................

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? ...hop yeast... neighbor's yeast
Did you make yeast for your own use? ...yes... Using starter? ...yes...
Using hops? ...yes... Salt rising? ...no...
Did you buy baking powder? ...yes... Baking soda? ...yes...
Cream of tartar? ...yes... Did you make your own baking powder? ...yes...

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? ...yeast...using starter? ...yeast...using starter? ...yeast...
Using hops? ...yes...Salt rising? ...yes...
Did you buy baking powder? ...yes...Baking soda? ...yes...
Ground of tartar? ...yes...Did you take your own baking powder?

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ... Apamap dug in nearest. Birch.

How far was this water from your home? Well in yard, spring 1/4 mile.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ........................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We had well in yard and often had to draw water and store in well. In 1935 got a dug out and had a filtered well in connection with it.
Apples - Fresh 1896 #2 - 3 barrel
dried 1920
Lettuce 1920
Tomatoes - Fresh 1920
canned 1900
Bananas 1900

Beefsteak 1832
Cornflakes 1914
other prepared breakfast cereals - five
Pearl tapioca 1840
"Minute tapioca 1830
Sugar 1890
Dates 1900
Salt nuts 1900
Icing sugar 1895

12. WATER SUPPLY
There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, durout)
If or far was this water from your house? (well, river, tank)
How was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel)

We need well and had to draw water and store in well. In 1935 got a dug out and had a buried well in summer with A.

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) ... Spring, well, spring, well.

How far was this water from your home? Well in yard, spring ¼ mile.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ..........................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We had well in yard and often had to draw water and store in well. In 1935 got a dug out and had a filtered well in connection with it.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did not water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, cistern)

If or for water this water from your house? Will you need any water?

How was it brought to the house? (Well, barrel, tank)

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started homesteading, giving dates where possible.

We had well in sand and often had to draw water and store in well. In 1935 got a dug out well and a filtered well in connection with it.
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, did you use lye? What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Where did you get your fuel?

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping.

First drew wood from Moose Mountain. Later grew the tree on our own place. Then drew coal from near Eaton. Still use Davis coal.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove made?

What year was it purchased? Price?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade)

For preparing food? (Chins, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)

When did you first see enamel ware? Aluminium?

1895

1910
12. STAPLES

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? If you made your own, what was it made from?

If you bought your own, did you use it regularly?

What kind of laundry soap did you prefer?

13. FULL

That fall did you use in the north east states?

Where did you get your fuel?

Was there any chance in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started here?

First started here in 1879.

Just moved from our own place.

Peter grew the wheat on our own place.

Then they used wood.

Still we burned wood.

14. HEATERS OR WAYS OF KEEPING WARM

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days?

(Gave dates)

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)

By whom was your first cook stove used?

That year was it purchased?

That type of stove did you use? (Iron, copper, etc., homemade)

For preparing food? (coal, wood, charcoal, wood, oil, etc.)

When did you first use electricity?

1875

1895

1910
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast - oatmeal porridge - eggs - toast
Dinner - potatoes, salt pork, bread, butter, batter pudding or custard
Supper - fried potatoes, more salt pork, boiled eggs - bread & butter - dried or preserved wild raspberries or buckthorn - which was plentiful in the mountain area

The Christmas of 1882 - we went back to Portage la Prairie for

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada?

Give the month. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

1883
Pork roast - potatoes & carrots
Peas - a steam pudding with raisins
dried apple pie
Wm & Eliza Higgins - family of 4 boys + 2 girls age from 9 to 12
Robert & Margaret Higgins - family of 2 boys + 1 girl age from 12 to 3 yrs
Robert & Sarah Montgomery and daughter age 3 yrs

No other neighbors within 20 miles

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

NO - We have been without sugar and tea for months but always had flour. And we brought hens and pigs from Ontario - there was no sale for the produce so we always lived very well if often very plain.

Robert Higgins' family have made $10 worth of sugar last for nearly a year.
Breakfast: oatmeal porridge - apple - toast

Dinner: potatoes, beef roast, bread, butter, molasses

Pudding or custard

1883

Pan - steam pudding with sour milk
Apple pie - apple pie filling
Robert & Eliza Wiggins - 2 children age 3 yrs
Roland & Harold Montgomery - 20 years

No - we have been without sugar and tea for months just doing hard work and we haven't had any and have been without sugar and tea for months just doing hard work and we haven't had any.

The Wiggins family has made $10 worth of very pleasant family hours.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In those early days, everything was cooked in black iron kettles or pots—we still have one at home—no tin enamel ware or aluminum. We had heavy iron frying pans and griddles.

Today we have pyrex bake ware and pressure cookers.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

About 1900 when the railway went through and the town of Weyburn came into being with its grocery and dry goods store.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

This questionnaire is made out by the family of William & Eliza Wiggin—The person making it out was 16 when we came to the West in 1882 and lives at Weyburn, Sask.

If any further information is wanted write Beryl Sather—Weyburn, Sask.
20. Notation any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the
earliest days compared with today.

In those early days everything was cooked in bulk
from scratch or from canned goods. We had to rely
on our own skills and knowledge. We had to
learn how to make our own bread, and preserve
our own fruits and vegetables.

Today we have many more options and convenience
cooking.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead
of preparing all our own food? (Give an exact date and place.)

About 1900 when the railway went through and
the town of Waukon came into playing with its quaint
and dry gravel store.

22. Plan to list other details from your early experiences of buying groceries
and preparing foods in your town for your posteriors. Include any
special memories or stories about your childhood.

This questionnaire is made out by my family.
It was filled out when we came to see what in 1882
and given at Waukon, Iowa. It included
many further information wanted
while raising another - William Hask.
